reasoning: The transcription details the process of cooking eggs in various ways, including hard-cooked, off-mollet (softer), and poached eggs. The steps are extracted based on the chronological instructions given by Jacques Pepin, focusing on the key actions required to achieve the desired results for each type of egg preparation.
dish_description: The video demonstrates multiple methods for cooking eggs: hard-cooked, off-mollet, poached, and low-temperature cooked eggs. Each method results in a different texture and doneness suitable for various preferences and presentations.

cooking_steps.description: Make a small hole in the round part of the egg to release the air chamber pressure and prevent cracking when placed in boiling water.
Place the eggs in boiling water with a gentle boil to avoid toughening the albumin (egg white).
Cook large eggs for 10 minutes and off-mollet eggs for 7 minutes in the boiling water.
Immediately transfer the cooked eggs to ice-cold water to stop the cooking process and prevent a green tinge around the yolk caused by sulfur reacting with the yolk's iron.
For poached eggs, use water with a little bit of vinegar to prevent the egg white from spreading too much.
Break the egg into barely boiling water and cook for 4 to 6 minutes, depending on desired doneness, using a slotted spoon to help it stay together.
After poaching, trim any excess egg white and keep the poached eggs in cold water until ready to serve, reheating them in hot water for 20 to 30 seconds.
For low-temperature cooked eggs, cook the eggs at 150 degrees Fahrenheit for 1 hour, resulting in a moist texture where the yolk and white are similar in consistency.
